title: Overseas collectivity
text:
The <a href="France">French</a> overseas collectivities ("" or "COM"), are first-order <a href="administrative%20divisions%20of%20France">administrative divisions of France</a>, like the <a href="regions%20of%20France">French regions</a>, but have a semi-autonomous status. The COMs include some former French <a href="Overseas%20territory%20%28France%29">overseas colonies</a> and other French overseas entities with a particular status, all of which became COMs by <a href="Constitution%20of%20France">constitutional</a> reform on 28 March 2003. The COMs differ from <a href="overseas%20department%20and%20region">overseas regions and overseas departments</a>, which have the same status as <a href="metropolitan%20France">metropolitan France</a> but are located outside Europe.
As integral parts of <a href="France">France</a>, overseas collectivities are represented in the <a href="French%20National%20Assembly">National Assembly</a>, <a href="French%20Senate">Senate</a> and <a href="French%20Economic%20and%20Social%20Council">Economic and Social Council</a> and can vote to elect members of the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a> (MEPs). The Pacific COMs use the <a href="CFP%20franc">CFP franc</a>, a currency <a href="Fixed%20exchange-rate%20system">pegged</a> to the euro, whereas the Atlantic COMs use the <a href="euro">euro</a> itself. 
As of 31 March 2011, there were five COMs:
